item.title: Getting rich equally
item.description: According to demographic theory, family size declines with rising prosperity. Meanwhile, human impacts on ecosystems are widely believed to be a factor of prosperity and population.

item.title: Living time
item.description: In my experience, a strange thing happens when you start to use a bicycle as transport: walking suddenly seems hopelessly slow. Presumably if you upgrade to a scooter, the bike in turn will immediately appear a waste of time. Certainly, to people who fly regularly, even high-speed trains seem as plodding as treacle. Five hours, you say? Impossible.

item.title: Filter versus search
item.description: America has a great tradition of corporate euphemism. Lobbyists are "public affairs consultants". Used cars are "pre-owned", and even "pre-loved".

item.title: Prosperity without growth
item.description: I am sold on Tim Jackson's theoretical "economics for a finite planet".

item.title: Ditch the quote
item.description: According to received wisdom, email is obsolete. Partly for intractable technical reasons relating to security. But also because it encourages people to compose messages like 19th-century letter-writers, with lots of "Dear so-and-so" and "Best regards", when they should be firing off laconic one-liners and generally getting to the point.

item.title: Creative federalism
item.description: Is it possible to be "united in diversity"? The EU's motto expresses the ambiguity at the heart of federalism, and so fuels the fear that underlies EU-scepticism.

item.title: Defining the web
item.description: Like all responsible citizens, I back up my files both locally and online. My online backup service has a web interface, which is occasionally useful but also uncomfortable – after all, it means my private files are technically "on the web".

item.title: RSS forever
item.description: RSS, the dumbest-named idea since the Ford Edsel. And also one of the best. Here are the three reasons RSS beats Twitter without a fight.

item.title: Link pages only
Pronouncing Linux
item.description: What a mess Linus Torvalds made when naming his kernel. According to the rules of English phonics, it should be pronounced "laɪnəks" ("lye-nooks"). But since many English speakers never absorbed phonics, a lot of people were soon calling it "lɪnəks" ("linnooks", which would be "linnux" under phonics). Linus at first gave his blessing to this latter, incorrect pronunciation (which is the most popular), before explaining that he himself pronounces it something like "liːnʉks" ("leenooks'") – the way it is said in every language but English. I suggest we copy him. English just isn't up to the job.
